accused.name: La Grande Lucye (Lucie, widow of Guyot Bozieres)

confession.devil_appearance: appeared in form of Mre. Romary
confession.seduction_context: Husband came home drunk while she was preparing bread, tried to attack and beat her, she fled to garden. While in terror that he might throw baby into heated oven, the enemy appeared to her in form of Mre. Romary and seduced her
powder_types: magical powder given by master for killing animals and people
sabbat_activities: sometimes beaten for refusing to do master's will
sometimes dreamed she was there, other times actually present

witnesses.name: Claude Borrellier
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: brother-in-law (Lucie was 'soeur germaine' to his wife Francoise)

testimony.quarrel_subject: Sale of house they shared in faubourg - his wife's property with Lucie as prospective heir. Lucie expressed discontent about the sale at poisle of Nicolas Claudiat
testimony.threat_quote: des deniers en provenans elle ne s'en serviroit en bonne santé

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: last summer (after apple given), died a week later

testimony.quarrel_subject: Lucie failed to sell 3 linceux de courtine (bed curtains), buyer withdrew, witness sold them herself so Lucie didn't get commission
Her son Jean Flaux had argument with Lucie while learning trade of weaver

witnesses.name: Agnez
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: daughter of deceased Jean de Vaubexey alias Thiery

testimony.threat_quote: tu as raporté que j'estois cause de la mort de Libaire, et que je luy avois porté des poires, Je t'asseure que tu t'en repentiras, tu ne mouras jamais d'autres mains que des miennes

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: within two hours Lucie brought pears

testimony.quarrel_subject: Endless arguing - he and wife left house they shared with her because they wanted peace

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: two days after Lucie looked in cot and said it was fine child

witnesses.name: Mongeon
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: wife of Demenge de But tabellion

testimony.quarrel_subject: Her husband rebuked Lucie for begging when she had some property and two daughters who could support her
testimony.threat_quote: que c'estoit honte à elle de demander l'aulmosne, attendu qu'elle avoit quelque commodité et deux belles grandes filles qui pouvoient bien l'entretenir sans ainsy mendier
Nicolas je suis femme de bien je vous prie de n'avoir aucun soubcon sur moy encor que j'ay plusieurs fois niché votre enfant

testimony.quarrel_subject: A song he and others had sung about her, her daughters, and some Religieux of Belchamps where they often went - a Religieux beat him one day at Belchamps because of this

witnesses.name: Idatte
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: neighbour, wife of Claude Barbonnaire harquebusier

witnesses.name: Gille Joseph
witnesses.occupation: archer de la garde de S.A.

witnesses.name: Chesnon
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: widow of deceased Linard Martin, former neighbour

testimony.quarrel_subject: Numerous quarrels when Lucie was their neighbour over last 5-6 years

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: day of Easter during mass, after not asking Lucie's pardon

witnesses.name: Bastienne
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: widow of Demenge Ferry, former neighbour 12 years before

testimony.quarrel_subject: Dispute over picking peas in garden with one of Lucie's daughters
Lucie was angry because she had not brought bread from Mirecourt or 'connieres' from Nancy when asked

timeline.subject: la Rondelatte
timeline.details: Execution of la Rondelatte, who denounced La Grande Lucye

timeline.subject: La Grande Lucye
timeline.details: PG des Vosges orders prévôt of Charmes to investigate reputation of La Grande Lucye

timeline.subject: La Grande Lucye
timeline.details: Additional confessions of malefices, interrogated twice same day

timeline.subject: La Grande Lucye
timeline.details: PG des Vosges asks for question ordinaire et extraordinaire

timeline.subject: La Grande Lucye
timeline.details: Change de Nancy approves death sentence on basis of existing evidence; she should only be shown instruments of torture while being questioned on witness allegations

torture.restrictions: Change de Nancy approved death sentence and said she should only be shown instruments while being questioned on witness allegations - prévôt disregarded this and had her racked

accomplices_named.name: tisserande of Chamagne
accomplices_named.context: Recognized at sabbat, had been in prison for a long time - later withdrew accusation

accomplices_named.name: Claudon Blanpoil
accomplices_named.context: Lucie claimed he bewitched her husband to death about 20 years before

prior_accusations.context: Denounced at her execution on March 11, 1608
Had accused Lucie in previous trial but withdrew accusation later

notable_quotes.speaker: La Grande Lucye (threat to Francoise Borrellier)
notable_quotes.french: des deniers en provenans elle ne s'en serviroit en bonne santé
notable_quotes.english: she would not use the money from [the sale] in good health
notable_quotes.context: Lucie's discontent at sale of house to Claude Borrellier, reported by Marie wife of Cuguin Flaux

notable_quotes.speaker: La Grande Lucye (threat to Agnez)
notable_quotes.french: tu as raporté que j'estois cause de la mort de Libaire, et que je luy avois porté des poires, Je t'asseure que tu t'en repentiras, tu ne mouras jamais d'autres mains que des miennes
notable_quotes.english: you have reported that I was the cause of Libaire's death and that I brought her pears, I assure you that you will regret it, you will never die except by my hands
notable_quotes.context: Threat to Agnez after she publicly blamed Lucie for death of servant girl Libaire

notable_quotes.speaker: La Grande Lucye (to Nicolas Gegoult at son's burial)
notable_quotes.french: Nicolas je suis femme de bien je vous prie de n'avoir aucun soubcon sur moy encor que j'ay plusieurs fois niché votre enfant
notable_quotes.english: Nicolas I am a good woman I pray you not to have any suspicion of me even though I have rocked your child many times
notable_quotes.context: Lucie's protestation of innocence at burial of Nicolas Gegoult's son

notable_quotes.speaker: Demenge de But (rebuke to Lucie)
notable_quotes.french: que c'estoit honte à elle de demander l'aulmosne, attendu qu'elle avoit quelque commodité et deux belles grandes filles qui pouvoient bien l'entretenir sans ainsy mendier
notable_quotes.english: it was shameful for her to beg alms, given that she had some property and two fine grown daughters who could support her without begging like this
notable_quotes.context: Husband of witness Mongeon rebuked Lucie for begging

notable_quotes.speaker: Bastienne (threat from Lucie)
notable_quotes.context: Threat to Bastienne after dispute over picking peas

notable_quotes.speaker: Chesnon's daughter Catherine (about confession)
notable_quotes.french: l'accident que luy arriva le jour de pasques pendant la grande messe ne luy fut venu sy elle luy eust demandé pardon
notable_quotes.english: the accident that befell her on Easter day during high mass would not have come if she had asked [Lucie's] pardon
notable_quotes.context: Catherine fell into swoon on Easter after returning from confession without asking Lucie's pardon

notable_quotes.speaker: La Grande Lucye (confession about husband's bewitchment)
notable_quotes.french: qu'environ septs ou huits mois avant son decès ledit Blanpoil qui avoit este appellé sorcier par un sien frere, invita sondit marit à boire, tellement que retornant d'avec luy, dit qu'il l'avoit fait boire en son verre et qu'il se trouvoit fort mal
notable_quotes.english: about seven or eight months before his death, said Blanpoil who had been called sorcerer by one of his brothers, invited her husband to drink, so that returning from him, he said he had made him drink from his glass and he felt very ill
notable_quotes.context: Lucie explaining how she knew Claudon Blanpoil had bewitched her husband

relationships.evidence_text: widow of Guyot Bozieres of Charmes, miller
Lucye as her 'soeur germaine' was prospective heir
fille de feu Jean de Vaubexey alias Thiery
femme de Demenge de But tabellion
her son Nicolas, aged about six
her cousin Francoise Philipe of Charmes

economic_context.details: Multiple economic tensions: sale of shared house with Borrellier family where Lucie lost inheritance rights; failed commission on sale of bed curtains; begging despite having property and two daughters; disputes over payment for day labour; poverty forcing reliance on alms; witnesses noting she had 'quelque commodité' but still begged; quarrel over payment for wheat at Ville-sur-Madon

harms_catalog.harm_description: strange sickness, all bent so that she could not walk, had to be carried like a child
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Sale of shared house, Lucie's discontent expressed at poisle of Nicolas Claudiat

harms_catalog.harm_description: death following worsening of illness after eating apple
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: died a week after eating apple

harms_catalog.victim_name: Nicolas (son of Margueritte Harmant and Nicolas Gegoult)
harms_catalog.harm_description: fell violently ill, died around midnight, something dropped from his bed before death
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Failed commission on sale of 3 linceux de courtine
harms_catalog.method_alleged: bewitchment, Lucie came to house during illness asking husband to sharpen hatchet

harms_catalog.victim_name: Jean Flaux (son of Marie and Cuguin Flaux)
harms_catalog.harm_description: bouts of insanity lasting up to 3 days
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Argument with Lucie while learning weaving trade with Claude Borrellier

harms_catalog.victim_relationship_to_witness: servant girl taken into her house
harms_catalog.harm_description: right arm and thigh full of 'cloux' (boils/sores), became worse after eating pears and died
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Lucie refused Libaire shoes when in service of Gille Choisy, tailor
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: within two hours of arrival at Agnez's house, Lucie brought pears

harms_catalog.harm_description: daily 'tintamarre' in her room for 3 weeks around St. Jean, small stones falling on her
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Agnez publicly blamed Lucie for Libaire's death

harms_catalog.victim_name: Baby of Mengeotte and Guillaume Redoubte
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: two days after Lucie looked in cot and said it was fine child, died next day
harms_catalog.method_alleged: evil eye / bewitchment through gaze and words

harms_catalog.victim_name: Nicolas (son of Mongeon and Demenge de But)
harms_catalog.harm_description: fell ill with unknown illness and died 'pitoiablement'
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Husband had rebuked Lucie for begging when she had property and daughters to support her

harms_catalog.harm_description: fell ill, felt worse after Lucie gave her 'verge' as remedy, cured after pilgrimage to Rebrimont
harms_catalog.method_alleged: bewitchment, false cure with 'verge' made it worse

harms_catalog.harm_description: dropped to knee and let go of arquebus as if something was making him do this, after Lucie stared at him
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: two years earlier, near the étang

harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Gille Joseph had called her witch and threatened to have her burned
harms_catalog.method_alleged: bewitchment out of hatred and envy

harms_catalog.harm_description: fell into swoon on Easter day during high mass, seemed like she would die
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Returned from confession without asking Lucie's pardon

harms_catalog.harm_description: vomited up a creature a foot long which made terrible smell when thrown on fire
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Multiple quarrels when Lucie was neighbour

harms_catalog.harm_description: fell ill and died with sickness similar to that of Libaire
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Dispute over picking peas in garden with one of Lucie's daughters

material_culture.context: Shared house in faubourg sold by Claude Borrellier, his wife's property with Lucie as prospective heir
3 bed curtains Lucie undertook to sell for Margueritte Harmant but failed to complete sale
Apple sent by Lucie to Francoise Borrellier, eaten before death
Lucie asked Nicolas Gegoult to sharpen her hatchet during son's illness
Two pears brought by Lucie to dying servant girl Libaire
Lucie refused Libaire shoes when in service of Gille Choisy, tailor
Given by Lucie to Idatte as remedy, made her feel worse
Gille Joseph's weapon he dropped when Lucie stared at him
Libaire failed to bring bread from Mirecourt for Lucie when asked
Libaire failed to bring 'connieres' from Nancy for Lucie when asked
Magical powder given by devil/master to kill animals and people
Claudon Blanpoil made Lucie's husband drink from his glass, causing illness
Lucie feared drunk husband might throw baby into heated oven while she was baking bread
Jean Mallebarbe broke a 'hape' he was supposed to be mending for Lucie
Girl snatched coiffe from head of one of Lucie's daughters at Ville-sur-Madon
Woman at Ville-sur-Madon stole 'du filet et de la chanvre' from Lucie
Woman at Ville-sur-Madon stole hemp from Lucie
Woman refused to pay for wheat from Lucie at Ville-sur-Madon
Dispute over picking peas in garden between Bastienne's husband and Lucie's daughter

spatial_references.context: Primary location of trial, where Lucie lived in widowhood and most witnesses resided
Where shared house between Lucie and Borrellier family was located
Where Lucie and husband took mills, site of devil's seduction and multiple confessed malefices
Where Lucie and husband took mills, site of confessed killing of 3-year-old girl and woman who took water
Where Lucie's husband died, Sr. Maillard certified her good character from there
Home of Claudon Blanpoil, who Lucie claimed bewitched her husband
Origin of servant girl Libaire who died
Religious house where Lucie's daughters often went, subject of mocking song by Cuguin Flaux and others
Pilgrimage site where Idatte and family went to be cured
Home of curé who prescribed drink to Libaire
Where Lucie asked Libaire to bring bread from
Where Lucie asked Libaire to bring 'connieres' from; location of Change de Nancy court
Home of tisserande (weaver woman) Lucie claimed to see at sabbat, later withdrew accusation
Where Lucie demonstrated discontent about house sale
Where Gille Joseph saw Lucie and she stared at him
Where Lucie fled from drunk husband and was seduced by devil; where Chesnon saw her rolling on ground
Where Lucie put powder that killed both her horse and another attacking it
Where Didier Bartremin and sons of Jean de Socourt saw two animals fighting, then Lucie emerged 'toute dechevelée'

economic_hardship_indicators: Lucie relied on alms/begging despite having some property
Lucie did day labour and spinning
Multiple disputes over small economic matters (commission on curtain sale, payment for wheat, etc.)
Husband rebuked for begging when daughters could support her
religious_calendar_references: St. Jean (stones falling on Agnez for 3 weeks around this feast)

legal_context.imprisonment_conditions: imprisoned after accusation by la Rondelatte about a month before interrogation

hearsay_chains.content: Lucie's discontent and threatening words at poisle of Nicolas Claudiat about house sale proceeds
General repute about Lucie and taking apple to Francoise Borrellier
Bore witness to illness of Libaire and stones falling on Agnez

emotional_state_notes: seemed to cry without tears when confronted with reputation
suddenly fell on knees to confess truth
begged not to be racked harder lest it cause her to tell lies
said she did not fear torture before being racked

reproaches_to_witnesses.objection: Said Catherine Martin fainted because she was subject to 'mal St. George' (epilepsy), not bewitchment

third_parties.name: Francoise Borrellier
third_parties.context: Died of illness attributed to Lucie after eating apple, sister and co-heir of house

third_parties.name: Nicolas (son of Gegoult)
third_parties.context: Aged 10, died after mother's quarrel with Lucie over commission, Lucie 'niched' (rocked) him

third_parties.name: Jean Flaux
third_parties.context: Aged 22, suffered bouts of insanity after argument with Lucie while learning weaving

third_parties.name: Libaire of Bralleville
third_parties.relationship_to_witness: servant taken in by witness 6, confirmed by witness 9
third_parties.context: Young girl who fell ill with 'cloux', died after eating pears brought by Lucie

third_parties.name: sons of Jean de Socourt
third_parties.context: Two sons now absent from Charmes, were cutting wood when they saw fighting animals then Lucie emerged disheveled

third_parties.name: sieur de But, tabellion
third_parties.relationship_to_witness: employer of Libaire, husband of witness 9
third_parties.context: Libaire fell ill in his service before being taken to Agnez's house

third_parties.name: Gille Choisy, tailor
third_parties.context: Libaire was in his service when she refused Lucie some shoes

third_parties.name: Woman of Charmes (suicide victim)
third_parties.context: Committed suicide 10-12 years earlier, Lucie spoke about devil being tempter after this event

third_parties.name: Man dressed in black
third_parties.context: Lucie claimed she woke in fields years before to find man trying to make her believe in him, sent him away

third_parties.name: Nicolas Claudiat
third_parties.context: His poisle (house/room) was where Lucie demonstrated discontent about house sale

third_parties.name: Catherine Martin
third_parties.context: Fell into swoon on Easter after not asking Lucie's pardon after confession

third_parties.name: Guillaume Redoubte
third_parties.context: Father of baby Lucie allegedly killed by looking in cot

third_parties.name: Claude Barbonnaire, harquebusier
third_parties.context: Husband made pilgrimage with Idatte to Rebrimont for cure

third_parties.name: curé of Gripport
third_parties.context: Prescribed drink to Libaire before she vomited creature

third_parties.name: Religieux of Belchamps
third_parties.context: Subject of mocking song about Lucie's daughters visiting them, one beat Cuguin Flaux

third_parties.name: la Rondelatte
third_parties.context: Executed March 11, 1608, denounced Lucie triggering investigation; seen at sabbat

third_parties.name: Jean de Socourt
third_parties.relationship_to_accused: accused her in previous trial, withdrew accusation
third_parties.context: Previously accused Lucie but withdrew; she saw him at sabbat; now absent from Charmes

third_parties.name: la Mallebarbe
third_parties.context: Previous trial consulted by Prévôt, had not accused Lucie

third_parties.name: la Triffatte
third_parties.context: Previous trial consulted by Prévôt, had not accused Lucie

third_parties.name: la Romaine
third_parties.context: Previous trial consulted by Prévôt, had not accused Lucie

third_parties.name: Mre. Romary
third_parties.context: Form the devil took when seducing Lucie 27 years before at Ville-sur-Madon

third_parties.name: Claudon Blanpoil
third_parties.relationship_to_accused: Lucie claimed he bewitched her husband to death
third_parties.context: Of Vaudeville, reputed sorcerer, Lucie said he killed her husband 20 years before by making him drink from his glass

third_parties.name: Francoise Philipe
third_parties.context: Of Charmes, Lucie confessed to killing her 4 years earlier after rebuke for begging

third_parties.name: Jean Mallebarbe
third_parties.context: Lucie confessed to killing him after he broke a 'hape' he was mending for her

third_parties.name: Girl of Ville-sur-Madon
third_parties.context: Lucie confessed to killing her for snatching coiffe from one of her daughters' heads

third_parties.name: 3-year-old girl at Gerbecourt
third_parties.context: Lucie confessed to killing her because mother had beaten one of Lucie's daughters who died afterwards

third_parties.name: Claudatte Flamant
third_parties.context: Of Charmes, Lucie confessed to killing her over quarrel about share of payment for day labour

third_parties.name: Catherine wife of late Claudon Jean
third_parties.context: Of Charmes, Lucie confessed to killing her 17 years before at her request, because she had let child be burned and feared husband's rage

third_parties.name: Woman of Gerbecourt
third_parties.context: Lucie confessed to killing her for taking water too often from their fountain

third_parties.name: Two women at Ville-sur-Madon
third_parties.context: Lucie confessed to killing one who stole 'du filet et de la chanvre', another who refused to pay for wheat

third_parties.name: Sr. Maillard of Cantenois
third_parties.context: Certified Lucie as good woman to 'gens de Justice' of Charmes when she took up residence

extraction_metadata.notes: Very detailed trial record with extensive witness testimony (17 witnesses) and multiple interrogations with confession. Trial initiated by denunciation from executed witch la Rondelatte. Lucie confessed to numerous malefices but retracted under torture. Notable legal irregularity: Change de Nancy approved death sentence and said to only show torture instruments, but prévôt actually racked her. Confession includes seduction story 27 years before trial. Economic tensions prominent throughout (property disputes, begging, failed business transactions). Multiple instances of food being vehicle for harm (apple, pears). Rich detail on community relationships and reputation lasting many years.
